data.text: Need a New Rack for Heavy Loaded Bike Touring

Now, racks. I've been using a no-name Alu tubing one, of a conventional if a little old-school design. It served me well, but it's about 15 years old, and is getting on a bit. Got a new bike, so I'm thinking maybe I should treat it to a new rack. Riding - heavy touring, with full 40ltr panniers, a tent, a top bag, a grab bag, and often water. We're talking 25+ kilos, sometimes 30+ (although I know some people prefer balancing the load along the bike, it works for me, so the question isn't about whether I should or shouldn't move some weight to the front). The bike is a 700c gravel one, flat mount disks, 142mm rear axle, rack mounts. Panniers are Ortlieb Back Roller. I have my eye on TorTec Expedition one, or perhaps the Epic. I particularly like the low and further-back extra rails: if there were anything I'd like different about my current rack, it would be lower rails and lower centre of gravity. Weight isn't a massive priority; a couple of hundred grams here or there don't matter, as I am only ever using it for big loads. So which one then? And there seem to be alloy or stainless options, stainless being a bit heavier, comparatively a lot pricier, and presumably somewhat stronger. I'd be happy with alloy, based on my past experience. Or are there any decent alternatives to TorTec, broadly along the same lines? Low rails, and something to put the panniers' bottom hooks over. Thanks! (this is a different bike on the picture, but that's how I'm loading stuff, just to give you an idea of what I am looking for)

I like the TorTec Expedition too myself, it is rated to 30KG. Some say alloy racks don't last as well as steel - perhaps the most recommended rack for your load would be the Tubus Cosmo or Logo - both rated to 40KG, but 3-4x the price of the TorTec.
data.author: Chris Van

data.text: Thanks Chris. 30 kilos should be enough - I ever go over it when loaded with food and water, so it diminishes in a day or two. And my current alloy rack served me for more than a decade without a fail, included through a fully loaded LEJoG, so I would be tempted to think that the 'stainless is stronger' argument is more along the lines of being technically correct in principle, but not necessarily relevant if alloy is still strong enough. Which panniers are you using yours with? The only concern I would have about Expedition is whether the bottom hook on Ortilebs will have something to latch on to.

data.author: Dave Ansell

data.text: Never heard of it, but it sounds possible - there are (or can be) all sorts of welds etc., and it's subject to a fair bit of vibration and stress, so I'd imagine fatigue might be building up. I reckon it's like breaking frames - I do know someone who managed, but only one, whereas lots of frame manufacturers talk about how their frames won't break (more than once). The trouble, I reckon, is how catastrophic such a failure would be - you can hardly fix it with a lick of gaffer tape.

data.text: Yeah, the material is stronger but that just means they can use thinner wall thickness tubes. For me it's the toughness - the bars won't get worn by the pannier clips like alu.
